title: Terror victims’ families back killing of ‘cowardly’ Isis leader al-Baghdadi
text:
Families of terror victims have welcomed the death of Isis leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi

Relatives of British terror victims have backed the killing of Islamic State (IS) leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, labelling him a ‘coward’ who lacked humanity and murdered innocents.

On Saturday, US Forces undertook a raid on the terrorist kingpin, with President Trump saying he died ‘like a dog’ after detonating an explosive vest and blowing himself up with three children.

Charlotte Coleman, whose daughter Olivia died in the Manchester Arena attack, told The Sun: ‘If they’ve killed him, good on ‘em. No one will ever forget what they’ve done.

‘Nothing will help at all with what I’ve been through, but at least they have done a good thing and got one of the leaders.’

Al-Baghdadi, the world’s most wanted terrorist, is thought to have inspired various incidents in the UK, including the Borough Market, Westminster Bridge and Manchester Arena attacks.

Mike Haines, whose brother aid-worker David was beheaded in Syria, added: ‘His evil and cowardly beliefs and actions lack any humanity and caused the death of many innocent people.’

Al-Baghdadi’s death, in Idlib, Syria, has led to fears of revenge attacks, with ex-army officer Abdullah Qardash expected to replace him as the leader of the organisation.

It has also sparked comparisons with the killing of former al Qaeda leader Osama Bin Laden, who died in a US military raid in 2011.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson tweeted: ‘The death of Baghdadi is an important moment in our fight against terror but the battle against the evil of Daesh is not yet over.

‘We will work with our coalition partners to bring an end to the murderous, barbaric activities of Daesh once and for all.’
